title: Synthetic Recap
body:
DETROIT (AP) – The Philadelphia 76ers came into The Palace of Auburn Hills with a superstar, but they left as witnesses to a one-man demolition derby.

Grant Hill didn't just beat the Sixers on this 1998 night; he authored a performance for the ages, a stunningly complete display of basketball virtuosity that powered the Detroit Pistons to a lopsided 115-78 victory.

From the opening tip, Hill was uncontainable. He slashed to the basket with a grace that defied physics and a force that shattered Philadelphia’s defensive schemes. When he wasn’t finishing at the rim, he was drawing fouls, marching to the free-throw line with a quiet, relentless determination. The points piled up—46 in total, a number that resonates with historic weight.

But Hill’s masterpiece was more than just scoring. He was the engine of the entire Pistons offense, dishing out 11 assists and orchestrating every possession with the poise of a floor general. He crashed the glass for 9 rebounds, falling just shy of a triple-double in a performance that felt more like a video game stat line than an NBA box score.

While Allen Iverson fought for his 21 points, he was a lone beacon in a sea of Pistons dominance, a dominance personified by the man wearing the blue and red. Hill’s historic night—46 points, 11 assists, 9 rebounds—wasn't just a win; it was a statement. On this night, Grant Hill wasn't just a star; he was the entire show, leaving an indelible mark on the franchise and the league.
